comments.text:
I speak only English, although for a while I spoke fairly decent  french. 
 However, you make the false assumption that this has to do with self 
absorption when it honestly has to deal mostly with practicality.  Many 
other countries have a much greater practical need for learning a diverse 
set of languages because their countries are far closer together.

America differs in both size and population size.  This means most 
Americans will rarely if ever run into a situation where there is a 
practical purpose in learning a new language.   Even many Americans who 
take the time to learn different languages (I studied french for six years) 
often lose their ability to speak it from lack of practice.

I also am making the point that you can hardly claim to be better for 
speaking too languages when you speak them poorly.  Many if not most 
Americans have spent at least a year learning a foreign language, but they 
don't claim they can speak it because they recognize they only understand 
it at a remedial level.

Finally, understand that despite not knowing other languages many Americans 
are still incredibly well educated on different cultures and ethnicity and 
in general have a greater understanding of global cultures then most other 
countries that have substantially less diversity within their own society. 
 I may not speak any other language, but I know a wide variety about the 
culture and history of south america, Germany, France, Spain, mexico, etc. 
 I've had conversations with people from across the globe from easy over a 
hundred different countries and I didn't even need to leave my home state 
or learn another language to do so.

Before you make claims about self absorption, I hope you realize that many 
american's probably have a far more broad global perspective then almost 
anywhere else on the planet.  The very fact someone thinks speaking their 
national language and English makes them less self absorbed shows how 
isolated they really are.

Anti-Abortionist, but anyone who is has probably made that choice 
voluntarily, so they are guilty just as someone who voluntarily joined the

I don't really care about being "dragged down to the enemy's level" in this 
situation, because in this war (which I think is true of many wars, 
actually) I don't believe there are any clear "good guys" or "bad guys". 
There are just two sides with contrasting opinions, both of which could be 
seen as potentially valid. I understand the viewpoint of Anti-Abortionists 
(I just don't agree with it): they believe that abortion is murder. With 
that view, it is perfectly reasonable to go around trying to kill 
Pro-Choicers: we are murderers in their eyes. If you or I saw 
someone trying to kill a one year old baby because they didn't want it, 
we'd probably be willing to use lethal force to stop that person from 
committing murder. To Anti-Abortionists, there is no difference between a 
one year old baby and a one month old embryo, so of course they believe 
that using lethal force to prevent the embryo from being killed is 
justified.

So I don't consider them "bad" people, I simply view them as a threat. I 
want abortion, and they want to take it away. So I want to get rid of them.

comments.text:

combatants? 'Total war' is generally opposed because in most wars it 
involves causing civilian casualties. But what I'm advocating is 
not attacks against "civilians" (non-Anti-Abortionists, in this case), I'm 
only advocating attacks against enemy 'combatants' (Anti-Abortionists). 
The war between Pro-Choicers and Anti-Abortionists is different to most 
other wars because it doesn't have to involve many civilian casualties: 
it's not like bombing entire cities and killing everyone there. In this 
war, we KNOW where the enemy is: in churches, in Crisis Pregnancy Centers, 
in right-wing households etc. What I'm suggesting is along the lines of 
waging 'total war' against the Taliban, while successfully avoiding causing 
huge numbers of civilian casualties. Is that so terrible?

In other words, if we could somehow evacuate all civilians from Iraq today, 
would it then be ethical to obliterate the country, since the only people 
left inside would be enemy combatants (e.g. Islamic State fighters)? I 
think that would be ethical. They are enemy combatants; they knew what they 
were 'signing up for' when they decided to join IS. They joined with the 
deliberate intention of destroying us. So would it be so unethical for us 
to destroy them? They aren't innocent civilians: they are 
deliberate fighters.

comments.text:
+MegaOpter You are the one who appears to have never researched the topics 
of free will, autonomy, causation or moral responsibility outside of 
reading what the bible says and simply accepting it. Your statements did 
not undermine or address the logic laid out in my previous arguments.

First, your statements didn't address the lack of freedom in a 'gun to 
head' scenario. I explained how God puts people in an analogous, but worse 
scenario and coerces worship through the threat of hell, you didn't address 
that at all.

Second, you state "Though God may know the way your life plays out, he 
doesn't plan it.". This is clearly wrong, since God designs you knowing 
what you will do. God designs you knowing what your life will be, meaning 
he chose to make you exactly how you are, knowing that doing so would cause 
you to live the exact life you have lived. If God chose to create you in a 
way that would lead to you do everything you do, and it knows everything 
you will do, then it chose  for you to live that life. God chose for you to 
do everything you do by designing you how you are. Simply stating "You're 
wrong because the bible says we have free will" does not allow you to 
escape that logic. 

Your statements also assume the existence of libertarian free will, (the 
idea that we can somehow perform actions in a way that was not ultimately 
determined by something outside of our control) which as I stated, is now 
widely accepted to be logically incoherent among the experts in the area in 
academia. Although there are many ways of showing this at many levels, 
perhaps the simplest way is the following:
1. All of your actions are necessarily based on your mental characteristics 
(e.g. what you find rational, convincing, what you desire, or value and so 
on)
2. You cannot choose the mental characteristics you start with, because 
choosing mental characteristics would require you to already have mental 
characteristics to make that choice based on.
Therefore, you must in some sense start with unchosen mental 
characteristics.If you are given mental characteristics and your choices 
are based on those unchosen characteristics from that point on, then all of 
your choices are determined by something you didn't choose.
comments.author: moyga

comments.text:
+athruz Yes, my conclusion very much does follow.  It is very simple.  If 
god is all knowing and all powerful, then he knows about every single child 
rape that occurs AND can stop it, but chooses not to.  There is no way 
around it.  You are stuck with that reality if your presumptions about 
omniscience and omnipotence are stipulated for the sake of argument.  Of 
course you say you reject it, but that is meaningless.  You simply don't 
want to acknowledge the reality of it.  You don't want to admit to yourself 
that god chooses to allow child rapes to be going on around the globe.  
People standing in judgment before god has nothing to do with the fact that 
he knowingly allows child rape, CAN prevent it, but chooses NOT to.  People 
paying for their acts has nothing to do with god's knowledge of child rape, 
having the power to keep it from happening, yet allowing it.

You are trying to excuse god's indifference and inaction.  There is no need 
to completely remove free will in order to prevent child rape.  He could 
simply only remove the horrific things from free will, and allow everything 
else.  That is, if he is actually all powerful.  And you insist that he 
is.  That means he can do ANYTHING.  He could make it so that no human 
being has the ability to rape anyone, let alone children.  He could have 
done that from the onset, but didn't, despite knowing everything that would 
ever happen, before ANYTHING had ever happened.  It really has nothing to 
do with how I feel about how he does things, but yes, I believe that raping 
children should never have been something that could possibly ever occur.  
There is no rationalizing it away.  I realize that you are trapped and 
can't get yourself to admit that your god is culpable for allowing 
uncountable child rapes, because you have it set into your brain that 
nothing about god could ever be even slightly imperfect, even when it is 
plainly demonstrated that what you believe can't be defended.  You are 
giving god a free pass because of your predetermined conclusions and 
beliefs.  Btw, quoting the bible doesn't do anything to demonstrate that 
the bible is true.  Of course, none of us were anywhere when the Earth's 
foundation was laid, 4.55 billion years ago, but again, none of that has 
anything to do with justifying the allowing of child rape.  Who said that 
any dimensions were "marked off"?  Where does that notion even come from?  
The Earth's foundation was determined by physics.  Duh.  There was no one 
to lay any foundation.  Why would you think that there had to be a 
someone?  This is getting way off track, and I bet that is your aim, but I 
will continue to address the religious nonsense you are spewing.

The fact the existence of any god can't be proven or disproven, and I will 
operate under your premise there, for the sake of practicality, in NO WAY 
grants creedence to any of the stuff you believe in that realm.  It is not 
equally likely that something is true or not based on the mere reality that 
it either is or isn't.  That doesn't make it 50/50.  I either can or can't 
pick up an SUV and spin it on my finger like a basketball.  The fact that 
it is either one or the other doesn't mean each reality is equally 
likely.  No, plausibility is NOT all you have to establish in order for 
your cuckoo belief system to be rational, and something literally being 
possible doesn't mean it is plausible.  You are misusing the term 
plausible, and it misrepresents the nature of your beliefs.  It is 
interesting that you went out of your way to make a semantic argument about 
the difference between proof and evidence, since I never mentioned proof, 
and yet all you went out to speak about were "evidences".  Proof can exist 
outside of the realm of mathematics, but more importantly, the "evidences" 
you named do not exist re: any god.  There is no evidence THAT your 
'creation' myth ever occurred, so you used a very basic circular argument 
on that one.  The fact that the universe exists is not evidence that any 
god exists.  We know the big bang was the origin of the universe as we know 
it, and not knowing what, if anything happened or existed before that is 
not evidence for any god.  It would be an argument from ignorance fallacy 
to insert god as an answer for something to which we don't know the actual 
answer. And religious people do that all the time.  VERY common.  Almost 
universal.  There is no logical argument that is sound that ends with the 
conclusion that there is a god.  Anyone that thinks so doesn't understand 
Logic and/or is being dishonest and is trying to make it seem like there is 
an actually sane basis to believe in their fairy tales.  There is no 
historical or archaelogical evidence of god, of course.  That is laughable, 
but not as laughable as "legal."  I would LOVE to know where that even came 
from.  LOL.  Again, your "plausibililty" line is absurd and amounts to 
nothing more than you starting from the presupposition that what you 
believe is true, and therefore everything you are saying automatically 
makes sense.  It doesn't.  You are putting the cart before the horse in the 
worst way.

You just contradicted the shit out of yourself.  You can't say that you go 
by faith, and then try to provide actual reasons for believing what you 
believe.  That is oxymoronic, when combined.  Faith is believing in the 
absence of evidence, but you are contending both are your reasons.  That 
doesn't fly.  And I have no reason to believe that god even exists, let 
alone that you know specific things about why he hasn't proven himself to 
exist.  And how silly that claim is.  It sounds like a child on a 
playground insisting to the other kids that he can fly, but just doesn't 
feel like it right now.  No one said faith is unnatural.  Again, where you 
got that is beyond me.  But no, we don't all live with faith, at least not 
in the sense that people have religious faith.  I have faith that the Earth 
will keep rotating for a very long time, causing what we call a sunrise to 
occur each day.  But isn't for the fuck of it.  I believe it because there 
is a basis to expect that it will keep happening based on observation and 
other scientific realities.  And why people "freak out about faith" is 
because you are believing absolutely childish, cartoonish nonsense, and not 
only is bad that you people base your life decisions on it as if affects 
YOU, but such things don't exist in a vacuum.  It can affect everyone else, 
especially children.  Believing things for horrible reasons is a very real 
problem, especially when those reasons include blind faith.

You don't know what credulity means, so you shouldn't be using the term.  
Credulity may or may not be an incarnation of blind faith.  And you also 
still don't know what faith means, as you described it exactly backwards.  
Faith has no evidence involved.  Having credulity may or may not.  Faith is 
having credulity in the willingness to believe something without evidence.  
Someone may have lots of evidence for something, leading to them being 
credulous about it.  But that isn't blind faith.  Blind faith is a form of 
credulity, but that doesn't mean that credulity is blind faith, and it 
certainly doesn't mean that someone that is credulous about something 
doesn't have a rational basis for it.  And AGAIN, you do NOT have evidence

comments.text:
+MMaximuSS1975 So are you capitulating on the "Jesus was Krishna" argument, 
or dogmatically adhering to it? The fact is that these superficial 
similarities do not constitute evidence, which is why they are generally 
dismissed by scholars. Horus, Krishna, Serapis, and even Julius Cesar have 
all been cited as purported explanations for Jesus, and all of them fail 
miserably upon scrutiny. Your assertion that no extra-bibical proof of 
Jesus exists, or that the evidence is scant, is false; there is plenty of 
evidence, and given that Jesus was a mere carpenter, the body of evidence 
for his existence is considerable. The greatest proof is the bible itself, 
specifically the gospels and letters of Paul, and they cannot be dismissed 
based on belief, or lack there of. This is apologetics, but it is also 
sound logic. Jesus couldn't have conceivably been Horus, Cesar, Apollonius, 
Krishna and Serapis, and the arguments that Jesus was someone else, or 
didn't exist, are so simplistic and flawed, that they have been either 
thoroughly dismantled or casually discarded by academicians and historians, 
including Bart Ehrman.

I am very familiar with Ehrman, and if you are too, you will know that his 
work deals primarily with biblical inerrancy. Even these arguments are 
weak, as the alleged proliferation of errors is explained by orthographical 
err, and have no bearing on the text's meaning. His arguments concerning 
the rhetorical discrepancies between the gospels are likewise unconvincing; 
though the narratives do differ in there portrayal of Jesus, there is no 
contradiction concerning the substance of what has transpired; it is simply 
a matter of different perspectives chronicling the same events.

There is no proof that can be presented that will convince you that Jesus 
is who he, his disciples, and I myself, say he is: Jesus is Lord. You seem 
like an intelligent individual, but you will never understand Jesus purely 
through intellect; what you need is an experience. I had many of the same 
objections and concerns that you have, but I realized that my own 
understanding is limited, decided to rededicate my life to the Lord, and I 
am glad. I'd be more than willing to share my experiences with you, but if 
not afforded that opportunity, I will simply ask that you open your mind 
and heart to the possibility that he is real. As for me, I am convinced 
that Jesus did not exist; rather, he existS, and he is Lord. Peace.
comments.author: UhuruSasa85

comments.text:
+MMaximuSS1975 So your contention is that these alleged "similarities" 
prove that Jesus was a myth? This is a weak argument. Consider the 
similarities between Abraham Lincoln and the late John F. Kennedy

Abraham Lincoln was elected to Congress in 1846. 
John F. Kennedy was elected to Congress in 1946. 

Abraham Lincoln was elected President in 1860. 
John F. Kennedy was elected President in 1960. 

The names Lincoln and Kennedy each contain seven letters. 

Both were particularly concerned with civil rights. 

Both wives lost their children while living in the White House. 

Both Presidents were shot on a Friday. 

Both were shot in the head. 

Lincoln's secretary, Kennedy, warned him not to go to the theatre. 
Kennedy's secretary, Lincoln, warned him not to go to Dallas. 

Both were assassinated by Southerners. 

Both were succeeded by Southerners. 

Both successors were named Johnson. 

Andrew Johnson, who succeeded Lincoln, was born in 1808. 
Lyndon Johnson, who succeeded Kennedy, was born in 1908. 

John Wilkes Booth was born in 1839. 
Lee Harvey Oswald was born in 1939. 

Both assassins were known by their three names. 

Both names are comprised of fifteen letters 

Booth ran from the theater and was caught in a warehouse. 
Oswald ran from a warehouse and was caught in a theater. 

Booth and Oswald were assassinated before their trials.

Using your line of reasoning, one could presume that John F. Kennedy was 
actually Abraham Lincoln. The only difference is that 2,000 have passed 
since the time of Yeshua, or Jesus, where as we are still living among 
people who saw, heard and and even spoke with Kennedy. We have no doubt 
that he existed; the same was true for Jesus; Paul the Apostle, Jesus' 
disciples, and even non-biblical scholars were equally convinced, but we 
are to believe that they were all either delusional, or coconspirators in 
an impossibly elaborate hoax. I'll pass on the Krishna; I think I'll have 
the Jesus.

comments.text:
+Nerobyrne First, the issue here IS pregnancy, not AFTER pregnancy.  
Abortion rights is the broad topic, and the specific issue is these clinics 
that deceitfully try to get women to think they are there to help them, 
rather than con them into not having abortions. The woman is free to choose 
whatever she wants regarding being pregnant.  Not wanting to pay child 
support is a completely separate topic that really should be addressed on a 
video that is about that topic.  That being said, I will address your 
thoughts on child support one more time...

One parent of the other is going to get primary custody in most cases.  
Equal custody is still fairly rare, even though it is much more common than 
it used to be.  I have a good friend who has equal custory with his ex, and 
neither pays child support, despite the fact that he makes far more than 
she does.  I don't mean for that anecdotal situation to be proof of a broad 
reality.  I am just pointing out that things have changed to some degree.  
Traditionally, the woman has been far more likely to get primary custody, 
which in and of itself makes it more of the man's burden to provide child 
support, since the woman is providing the primary home and care.  This has 
been especially true in the past,  Whichever parent is NOT providing the 
primary home and care IS generally going to be more liable for paying 
support.  That's just simple reality.  AND men STILL don't contend for 
primary custody nearly as often as women do, with there being a much more 
common situation of agreement that the woman will have primary custody 
without it being contended. You are arguing as if the common practice is 
for every couple to dispute over primary custody, AND you are contending 
that the man shouldn't have to pay for the child's support.  That is a 
preposterous coupling.  Does the man both want primary custody AND not want 
to provide for the child?  It is ridiculous, even theoretically.  If the 
man argues that he shouldn't have to pay child support because he never 
wanted the child, he is obviously not going to be given primary custody, 
ffs.  So that renders the complaint about not getting custody completely 
impotent for anyone that is contending, as you are, that not wanting the 
child is grounds to not pay for it, WHILE complaining that men don't 
get custody nearly as often.  If you want custody, you have no argument as 
to not wanting the child to exist.  That is simply absurd.  Again, only one 
parent is going to get custody in most cases, which means that the other 
parent is going to be liable to owe some support.  As far as the woman 
lying to you go, that is a fringe issue that would be practically 
impossible to prove, and MORE IMPORTANTLY, is ultimately irrelevant.  One, 
the woman could have been using contraception and gotten pregnant anyway.  
Two, THE CHILD EXISTS REGARDLESS OF THE CONDITIONS UNDER WHICH IT WAS  
CONCEIVED.  How does wanting the child or being aware of a pregnancy change 
the fact that you were the one that impregnated the woman and created the 
child that now exists and needs food, clothing, and shelter?  Who should be 
the parties that pay for that child's necessities and provide care for that 
child?  Society, who didn't have sex and create the child???  Or the people 
that DID have sex and create the child, whether they wanted to have a child 
or not?  The child exists and has to be provided for.  It is ridiculous for 
you to contend that the first line of support should be someone other than 
the parents.  If you don't want to make it possible for you to be 
responsible for providing for any children, don't have sex.  You are 
inherently assuming the risk of that reality when you choose to have sexual 
intercourse.
comments.author: slyjokerg

comments.text:
Wow. Just WOW.
You're assuming one hell of a lot with that, so let me dismantle it one 
assumption at a time.

Assumption 1: That I would have sex without contraception.
I have (and will until I'm thinking about having children) used birth 
control pills. I've been on them since I was 16. I also always insist that 
any sexual partners I have use a condom, as I am currently not in a 
relationship anymore it is even more important and immovable point if a guy 
wishes for sex from me. I currently have abstained for almost two years 
simply because I haven't been in a relationship, so your entire point using 
me as reference is total bullshit.

Assumption 2: That a one day old baby has a personality.
If you're literally talking about a day after conception... you're 
completely ignorant of facts. Until about the late second trimester, a baby 
is a clump of cells and then eventually begins to look like a shrimp, then 
a chick, THEN it begins to kind of look human. No study has even found 
brainwave activity until the third trimester. Without an active brain, 
there is no way a child has any kind of personality. Further sociological 
studies after children are born have pointed to at LEAST several months 
after birth to determine a 'personality' emerging. Differences in activity 
level/noise level, etc are almost certainly due to biological stimulants 
rather than internal thought processes; they have to be around long enough 
to have been influenced by the world in order to form a personality, as 
that comes from social and cultural interaction/experiences.
Also, if you believe a baby is a fertilized egg, then EVERY WOMAN on this 
ENTIRE PLANET that has ever had more than ONE PERIOD while she was in a 
consensual relationship and didn't use contraception is a MURDERER. That 
would make a massive number of women SERIAL KILLERS. Those fertilized eggs 
are flushed out with her period. Also would include the about 20% of 
fetuses naturally abort before a woman has any clue she's pregnant for a 
myriad of reasons. If nature can abort a child for reasons it deems 
'necessary', why can't we have enough reign over our own bodies with modern 
science to do so?

Assumption 3: That your argument (which is only based in emotional pleas, 
which you probably believe will work on me simply because I'm a woman) 
about viewing this from the child's angle would get me to change my mind.
First off: it's not a fuckin' kid. In my personal opinion, a kid doesn't 
really matter until it becomes self-aware (which is at about six months of 
age, usually). Until that point it is like a dog or cat -- you have to care 
for its needs and killing them is certainly abhorrent. BUT -- before a 
child is out of its mother's womb, it is nothing more than a parasitic life 
form that is causing the mother's body quite a bit of strain and has been 
for 9 MONTHS. If that said parasitic life form would cause the mother's 
death, if it is a product of rape, if it is the product of poor decisions 
(and thus will likely be forced into abject poverty or at least a family 
where the mother resents her own child because they stopped her from going 
places with her own life, [even though it was her issue of either being too 
lazy/ignorant/stupid to use some birth control method(s) or because she was 
already in such an abject poverty situation that she could not 
afford/receive birth control in the first place]) then the mother has all 
the right in the world to terminate HER pregnancy. I would carry no regret 
about terminating a pregnancy, because I would only ever do it in extreme 
circumstances (rape, if the baby was malformed and would live a horrible, 
painful life outside the womb). And, if I were the child (as you suggested) 
and you likely meant a clump of cells... I wouldn't have a clue that I was 
being aborted, so I wouldn't give two shits. If you believe in souls -- and 
I do -- then even if there's a soul already there, it will go into a 
different child, one that's wanted, one that will be happy with a loving 
family.


Final Points:
I'm sure I've repeated myself about several issues, but they are all 
important so I hope they finally sink in to your thick skull.
It isn't the right of white, privileged males to decide what does or 
doesn't go on in WOMEN'S bodies. The congressmen with the "legitimate rape" 
and "god-given rape" 'arguments' make it PAINFULLY clear that not only do 
they not know the first thing about what they are talking about and, at the 
same time, that they want women to suffer with their natural massive 
burdens in life for their religious fanatical caucus.

Also, the point about foster care is COMPLETELY relevant -- but, as usual, 
pro-lifers ignore the facts in order to attempt to bolster their case. The 
issue of abortion is heavily effected by the fate of the children that 
would be "saved" or aborted. It severely undermines pro-life stances to 
remind them of what happens to a vast majority of those babies (and the 
women they sometimes kill in order to be born or ruin the lives of).
Granted, I completely believe that there are a lot of people that are 
irresponsible and don't use birth control when they should be. HOWEVER, I 
don't believe that mistake should fuck up their entire lives -- thus my 
stance on this.

I'll stop fighting when it's safe, legal and nigh untouchable -- and, 
hopefully, at the same time the companies that claim birth control goes 
against their religious beliefs at least also ban Viagra and other such 
drugs (and penis pumps) but preferably realize how stupid their being and 
allow birth control back onto their plans. The stats of several other 
countries that have already settled this stupid debate point overwhelmingly 
to the idea that access to informative/comprehensive sex education, 
healthcare, birth control and legal abortion DRAMATICALLY reduces the 
instances of abortion as well as the numbers of children in foster care 
services.
